nodes.text: I trust that by now you have all mastered the art of using tools to pick locks, that you have your own rope and grapnel, and that you have studied your previous lessons for this test.

You will have four essay questions. When you have written your answers, you are dismissed from class to prove your lockpicking skills. Follow the instructions to open the assigned locker in the Locker Room.
We will meet again in two days' time. Macht's gut.
Of all the Rogue lessons we have covered in class so far, which one has personally been the most useful to you and why?

options.text: Write What You Think the Master Wants to Hear

nodes.text: So far, I've found that the stealth skill lesson on 'Stop, Look, and Listen' to be the most important advice in life.
I've always tended to rush in and do things without thinking about it. Now, I make myself look at the situation and what might happen before I act.
I think the lesson on Spot Hidden has been the most meaningful for me. It makes me look at things carefully to look to see if there is more to the matter than it seems.
It's not so much about seeing things, it's about thinking about things. It all comes down to using my brains, and so thinking is the most important Rogue skill of all.

The most important lesson taught
Was one I clearly needed a lot.
When doing something I should not
The rule should be to not get caught.
The lesson of the school thief taught me that I can be punished for someone else's crimes. It demonstrated clearly that life isn't fair and that I can't trust authority figures to help me.

You are in a tavern when a group of ruffians walk in through the door clearly intent upon causing trouble. They go up to a patron of the inn and deliberately insult him. The innkeeper looks pleadingly at you to do something to defuse the situation before it gets out of hand. What Roguish skill do you use to handle this situation?
I'd go up to the bullies and ask them what the matter was.
I'd invite them all to sit down with me and discuss the problems over a few drinks. I'd use flatter and charm to calm them down and stop causing trouble.
I'd yell out to everyone that 'drinks are on me - all you can drink for the next ten minutes!'
While everyone is rushing the bar, I hand the chief troublemaker a drink with sleeping powder in it.
Once he passes out, I take him outside, strip him naked, and leave him propped up on the front of the tavern to sleep it off.

I ask the innkeeper the name of the troublemaker. Then I sneak through the crowd and hide behind a table full of drunkards. I shout out the bully's name and say that he's the biggest coward in the whole room.
While he's trying to figure out who said that, I sneak to another part of the room and shout, "He's so stupid, he doesn't know that his friends hang out with him just to laugh at what an ass he is."
When the fight breaks out, I grab one of the combatant's mugs of beer, climb up to the rafters, and watch the entertainment from my vantage point.
I'd use my stealth skills and the 'Way of Godot' to sneak into the basement when the fight breaks out so I can drink all the free ale I want.
What Rogue tool or skill would you use to deal with a monster stalking through the Great Hall?

I set up a series of traps and then tease the monster to chase me out into the courtyard. As it chases me around the pool, it gets caught in the sequence of traps and I throw daggers at it while it's caught.
We play ring around the roses until I wear the monster down and finally dispatch it.
I make it a point of being charming, polite, and respectful to Mr. Terk whenever I see him in the Great Hall because it drives him crazy.
I go over to Lady Moira and let her know that there is a dangerous monster loose in the castle. Then I sit back and watch as the Paladins and Warriors deal with the situation.
I use the lesson of Godot and stealth to avoid the monster all together. Fighting monsters isn't in the Rogue's job description.
Why is "Thou shalt not steal... from classmate or the school" a Rule for Rogues?
If 'no stealing' wasn't a rule, we'd be so busy stealing from each other, cheating, and getting revenge, that we'd never learn anything else.
Even though this is a school for heroes, we Rogues are the outcasts and the misfits. We need to learn to trust one another. The friendships we make here can last our lifetimes.
The rule is there to make it clear to the powers that be that we aren't thieves. Terk hates the Rogue Class, but he has no good way to convince the Headmaster to expel us.
Unless, of course, one of us steals the Headmaster's hat.
So that the Master can cover his ass when others accuse him of running his own private Thieves' Guild here.

nodes.message: I feel like Urwald needs to say something like "Pens down" or "now that you're done with the written exam..." here

nodes.text: You have now completed the Essay section of this exam.

Your assignment is to:
1 - Go to the Lockroom
2 - Unlock locker number 13
3 - See what is in the locker
4 - Re-lock the locker without removing the object
5 - Report on the object you find in the locker in our next class in two days.

nodes.message: Shawn's Lock Test Score is ${ego.test2score} out of a possible 100.

nodes.name: Lock Test
nodes.description:
I need to unlock locker number 13 in the Lock Room to finish the Rogue quiz. Stupid test... Essay questions... I hate essay questions. 
Good news - no class tomorrow!
